lines.text: [Nadia fell from the balance beam twice at her first gymnastics competition, to the disgust of her trainers. She is sitting at the back of the bus on the way home. Bela goes and sits beside her]
Don't cry about today.
I'm not crying. I never cry.
You should. So that I could tell you not to. Nadia, the tragedy isn't that you fell. It's that you were the best, and you didn't live up to it! You completely lost your concentration!
It will never happen again. Never!
You're not serious about gymnastics.
Yes I am.
No you're not, you're just playing. You should quit.
No!
Did you ever see *anyone* as bad as you were today?
No.
Neither did I. Quit!
No!
Go back to the schoolyard and do cartwheels if you just want to play!
No! I want to be a champion!
[He hugs her as she starts to cry]

I'll confess something to you. I've been playing too. When I first found you, I only knew four sports. I wasn't even a real gymnastics coach. So I'll make a pact with you so we can both stop playing, hmm? Instead of teaching you what I don't know, I want to teach you what I do know. I will teach you how to have a runner's strength, the cunning of a handball player, and how, like a boxer, to be fearless of pain. You interested?
[Nadia nods]
I'm talking about a lot of work. Total commitment. Total concentration. Don't take up my time and then quit!
I'll never quit.
No one has ever worked as hard as I'm going to work you.
I shall work.
You do, and you will be the best in the world.
[At the Olympic Games, Bela gathers the Romanian gymnasts around him]
Listen to me. Don't let anyone's reputation intimidate you. All it means is that they used to be good. They must prove that they still are.
[Ludmilla Tourischeva sprints down the runway and executes a tucked Tsukahara vault]

[to Teodora]
They're still good.

[an injured Nadia starts preparing for competition]
What are you doing?
I will compete.
I can't let you.
What does the team need to win?
Nine-point-nine.
Tell the judges I'm competing.
Are you sure?
Tell them.
[Teodora transfers to the Karolyis' school and performs her floor routine for the other students. Everyone then leaves for the evening, except for her and Nadia]
You're the best here, aren't you?
[Nadia nods]
I knew it. Are you jealous?
[Nadia shakes her head]
Why not?
It was beautiful.

[notices Nadia looking unwell]
You all right? Hmm?
[Nadia squirms]
No, you're not all right. What did you eat last night?
[Nadia looks away and keeps stretching]
You went out, didn't you? How could you? Today of all days!
It won't matter.
I took an Olympic silver medal right next to you, and no-one even knows that I was there!
It's not my fault if people don't pay attention to you! I wish they would! I wish they'd leave me alone.
Does anyone want to tell me who the other cartwheeler was?
[looks at a student]
How about you?
[turns and stops in front of Nadia's desk]
I think you know who it is. And I'll bet that if you give her this card, she'll think about it and fill it out. Don't you?
Do you think it's possible for a little girl to fly?
[Nadia thinks for a moment, then nods]
So do I!
She's getting very good!
I suppose. But will all this make her happy?
Well, you just saw her; I have to order her to stop!
[the Romanian gymnasts have just walked in the parade of athletes at the Montreal Olympic Games and now stand before a huge crowd of spectators]

[whispering]
What do you think?

[whispering back]
Let's go home!
I'm sorry.
For what?
For being jealous. You deserve all your wins.
I have often wondered what would have happened if Bela had chosen you in Paris, instead of me.
So have I.
Is that how you talk about me when I'm not here?
No, I just...
You tell everybody I'm fat, right?
No...
Right?
I don't have to, Nadia. Look at you; you are fat.
Why don't you ask me questions about gymnastics?
[Bela and the girls have been sitting at the Paris airport for over two hours, waiting for their contact to meet them]
So, Nadia, how do you like Paris?
Wonderful. Especially the airport.

[the Karolyis' Deva team has just beaten the Bucharest national team in competition]
Congratulations.

[packing a kit bag]
Thank you. It is so good to finally beat the national -
[looks up and trails off when he sees Nicholae]
Hello, Bela. How is our top coach?

[sighs]
Hello.
Any new Nadias on your team?
There will never be another Nadia, and even if I had one, I wouldn't tell you.
Tell me about Emilia Eberle.
Emilia?
Yes.
Yes. You just saw her. She will win another gold before the evening is over.
Yes. Impressive. How old?
Twelve. The whole team is twelve. They are harder to *steal* when they're twelve.

[at dinner, discussing the upcoming Olympic Games in Montreal]
If we don't go, I'll tell everyone why. Including the press.
That would *not* be wise.
A-ha! Tell me, where are all the wise coaches?
I don't know.
That's because you've never heard of them. Being wise is not what we do best.

[holds up the soup tureen lid to cover Bela's mouth]
Would you like more, Mili?
Don't tempt me, Marta, thank you. Take care, Bela. Don't push too hard.

[puts his hand over Marta's and pushes the lid back onto the tureen]
*That* is what we do best.
You're late again, Teodora; that's two hundred sit-ups.

[sarcastically]
Why not make it four hundred?
Very good idea, make it four hundred.
So, Nadia, how do you like Fort Worth?
The judges were tough on you.
It was about right.
You usually do better. Judges resent the fact that little girls grow up.

Nadia, gymnastics has changed, and we're the ones that changed it. What used to be special is now ordinary. You and I, we can't compete with ourselves anymore! I wanted to help the team win if I could, but before Fort Worth, I had already decided to retire. It's tough being with a lot of twelve-year-olds that are better than I am...
They're not.
Not all of them. But they're getting better, and I'm getting worse! It's time.
What will you do?
Join the circus.
The circus?
Yeah. It'll be fun!

[about Nicholae Vieru]
He's very interested in our Onesti program. He sees you as the bright stars of our future.
[Nicholae walks to the Bucharest team and greets them with open arms and a flower bouquet]

[sarcastically]
Yes, I can see that.
How could that happen to her?
She's totally dependent on you.
What do you mean?
Bela, you didn't teach her to control her appetite; you took away her food.
Nadia is not dependent on me. She is irritatingly independent. She always fought with me.
And you always won.
Marta, I can't be with her forever. What will she do then?
That's a very good question.
Do you remember how long a day took when you were a child? A week. And a week lasted a month, and a month lasted a year!

[arguing with Nicholae about allowing the Onesti team to compete in a Paris gymnastics exhibition]
Nicu, you are the expert for men, I for women. Trust me! We have no better girls here, or anywhere else in Romania. The Karolyis are training champions!
I really do not like your man Karolyi. He is ruthless. He will do anything to win.
Yes, he will.
[grins]
Isn't that wonderful?

[watching Nadia train]
Bela, Nadia gets so intensely involved when she performs that she forgets the audience. But she never thinks to smile.
Geza! Teach her to smile! What judge would like such a sourpuss?
Nadia, concentrate. Forget *everything* but the exercise.

[sitting by an open window, whispers]
Teodora! Teodora! Psst! Over here! Smell that food?
Mmmm. What is it?
I don't know. But I like the way it smells!
Do you think they're dancing down there?
Maybe. I know they're eating, though.
I think we ought to sneak down there, don't you?
[Nadia shakes her head nervously]
Nadia - it's now or never!
Let's go.

[telling her father about the first day of school]
We have such fun! We run and jump into a big hole filled with bouncy things!
A big hole filled with bouncy things?
Another delicious carrot stick, my dear?
Which one is delicious?

[arguing over Nadia, who has gained weight and is out of shape]
She is not even training.
No. She is not. For the first time since she was six years old. But she will.
She must. I want you to confine her to the dormitory, and restrict her eating.
You want me to do that?
Yes. Now. And no visitors.
If you do anything to ruin this for her...
For *her*, Stefania? For *her*?
Over here!
[He runs and hurls himself into the jump pit. A few of the gymnasts follow. He starts throwing pieces of foam]
Come on in, the water's great!
[Giggling, the rest of the girls run and jump in]
You're supposed to be one of the coaches, not one of the children.
They like it!
I didn't bring you here to be liked.
Sometimes people just can't help themselves.

]
You must be the other one!

[smiling embarrassedly]
That's me.
[the eight-year-old Teodora has just performed an advanced floor exercise]
How can a little girl do that?
That's what comes from serious work.

'In Paris, Romanian gymnast Nadia Comaneci won the hearts of the audience in a surprise appearance. Professor Bela Karolyi stated that she is one of many top-caliber gymnasts currently training at his school, who will be competing at *all* of the upcoming European events.']
That is blackmail!

[laughing]
But he's right!
I still think you're pushing too hard. It's not the Olympics, you know.
It will be. Canada, Marta, we're going to Canada.
Bela!
[laughs incredulously]
Our girls are too young! They - they haven't even won a European event yet!
Yes. That's why we're going to Paris first.

[talking about the upcoming Olympics in Montreal and the difficulties of getting the Onesti team there]
You must understand Vieru's problem. Bucharest is the capital. It has the most expensive facilities, the most experienced coaches, and supposedly the best gymnasts.
Does Bucharest win medals? No. Onesti wins medals.
From now on, Nadia, it is up to you. You cannot depend on me anymore. I will teach you what to do. But I can't make you do it, and I won't do it for you.
What do you call *that*?
My new floor routine.
Where are the hand gestures?
I'm not a little girl anymore; I do not need hand gestures.
Nadia, ever since Montreal you've gotten...
I'm growing up. Can't you see?
Growing up. You call arguing with your coach growing up.
Those gestures are childish. I won't do them.
As long as you are in my gymnasium, you will do it my way. Do you understand? Do you?
Yes.
Yes what?
Yes. Comrade Professor.

[about Bela]
For years I have been putting up with that egomaniac!
He's winning.
I don't like him.
You like him to win, don't you?

[returns to the gym after taking a phone call]
Bela?
Yes?
The girls... they're gone.
What?
The team, they've been moved to Bucharest.
That's impossible.
It's true, Bela.
But we're their coaches!
Not anymore.
Nadia too?
All of them.
Family. For nine years, Marta, we were family!
I understand now.
You do?
I can do it on my own.
[smiles]
Thank you.
[the announcer calls her name, and Nadia goes to compete on the balance beam - by her own choice - despite a severe wrist infection]
What did you do to her?
For the first time - nothing!
